history.content:
I was under the impression that the limit does count as a graduation requirement. According to https://ls.berkeley.edu/advising/academic-progress/grades/passednot-passed-grades

  • Passed grades may account for no more than one third of the total completed units taken on the Berkeley campus at the time of graduation (includes Passed grades earned through the Education Abroad Program, UCDC, the University of California Intercampus Exchange Program, and University Extension).

It seems like if you do exceed the P/NP limit, you won't be able to graduate. I could be completely wrong but that was the impression that I got when reading this.

Friendly reminder to please not include policy links etc unless you know a student's college. This is a CoE student.

I'm not entirely sure how CoE calculates it, but I'm sure you could shoot a quick email to your ESS Adviser. For L&S, we calculated it as: 

120 UCB units needed to graduate x 2/3 needed letter graded = 80 letter graded units needed (for a freshman admit). If you had that, you're good and not punished for taking extra P/NP courses beyond the 120 requirement.

Friendly reminder to students to please not include policy links etc unless you know a student's college. This is a CoE student.

I'm not entirely sure how CoE calculates it, but I'm sure you could shoot a quick email to your ESS Adviser. For L&S, we calculated it as: 

120 UCB units needed to graduate x 2/3 needed letter graded = 80 letter graded units needed (for a freshman admit). If you had that, you're good and not punished for taking extra P/NP courses beyond the 120 requirement.

children.subject: Sorry about that, I forgot there were different policies for different colleges. I will be more careful next time!

history.content: If I have completed all of my degree requirements and am eligible to graduate, does the 1/3 P/NP unit limit still apply to me? What happens if I exceed the limit, but I completed all the degree requirements none the less?
history.subject: Pass / No Pass Limit
